J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Although I can relate to all the things you wrote, I'm stuck with one
> logical quandary.
>
> If Pluggable Selector is OK for JUnit, then why isn't it OK for the code
> I was writing, which happened to choose rule methods the same way JUnit
> chooses test methods?

It beats me if it's OK.  You asked what the difference could possibly 
be.  I laid out that the difference might be reuse patterns.  We 
disagree on this point, but I claim no knowledge of whether your 
original design was good.  Frankly, you sound like an experienced 
designer, and I like clever designs, so on that point, we may very well 
be on the same side.

> You wonder whether it matters how heavily reused the code is. So, if
> this is code only my team will use, then it's not OK; but if it's code I
> plan to put into a general-purpose, widely-used rule engine[1]

I'd be interested in what that footnote was supposed to be.  :-)

> , then
> it's OK. I don't buy that at all. Ignoring the effort to write the code
> this way, its value might increase the more it's used, but that doesn't
> mean it has negative value when it's not widely used. It would seem that
> the more people who try to use a clever design, the more that clever
> design costs, if you include the cost of supporting the people trying to
> use it. As a result, I'd argue the opposite: the fewer people who use
> it, the more we can afford to be clever.

Good point.  I wonder if there's a lot we could learn about the 
cost/benefit analysis of cleverness.  I think that the strongest claim 
we could probably agree on is that we're most likely to win if each 
person that learns the metaphor ends up using it thousands of times 
regularly, rather than a handful of times separated by months on end.

> In my case, JUnit /was/ the metaphor: rule methods are collected
> automatically like test methods, and if any rule fails, the whole
> ruleset fails. To anyone with any JUnit experience, I think that works
> well. This is why I was surprised to see many JUnit users balk at it. So
> there must be something else to it, and frankly, I can't see what it is
> beyond those people deciding arbitrarily. That's fine, but I don't want
> people to dress it up as more than that when that's what it is.

It sounds like this is a question you should address to those JUnit 
users.  Did they give you concrete feedback, or simply "Nope, don't like 
it", or was there another design that enthralled them?

Thanks,

    David Saff
